propertyGroup.name: Outlets
propertyGroup.documentation: Defines the locations to which output is generated.

property.name: configuration
property.documentation: The location to which configuration files are generated. These are the files that typically appear in WEB-INF, such as faces-config.xml, web.xml, etc.

property.name: exceptions
property.documentation: The location to which exceptions are generated.

property.name: custom-configuration
property.documentation: The location to which any customizable configuration files are generated.

property.name: custom-resources
property.documentation: The location to which any customizable resources will be generated.

property.name: libraries
property.documentation: The location to which JSF libraries will be generated (these are the libraries required for JSF support, myfaces libraries, etc). If this isn't defined, its expected that the libraries will be provided by another means.

property.name: controllers
property.documentation: The location to which any controllers are generated (this outlet contains classes which are fully generated and should not be touched).

property.name: controller-impls
property.documentation: The location to which controller implementations are generated (these are where your hooks go to your services).

property.name: managed-beans
property.documentation: The location to which any additional managed beans are generated (including layout options, etc).

property.name: messages
property.documentation: The location to which message resource bundles are generated.

property.name: services
property.documentation: The location to which any services are generated (this outlet contains classes which are fully generated and should not be touched).

property.name: service-impls
property.documentation: The location to which any services implementations that the must be edited

property.name: app
property.documentation: target/src/app folder.

property.name: css
property.documentation: Angular CSS folder.

property.name: angular-test
property.documentation: Angular tests folder.

property.name: shell
property.documentation: Where the auto generated application menus are saved.

property.name: ngrx-store
property.documentation: Top level directory for generating ngrx store files.

property.name: ngrx-store-impl
property.documentation: Top level directory for editable ngrx store files.

property.name: shell-impls
property.documentation: Where the application menus.

property.name: components
property.documentation: Where the application components are output.

property.name: components-impl
property.documentation: Where the application components implementations are output.

property.name: views
property.documentation: Where the application views (JSPs, Facelets, etc) are output.

property.name: view-impls
property.documentation: Where the application views are output.

property.name: test
property.documentation: Where the application tests are output.

property.name: test-impls
property.documentation: The location to which test implementations are generated.

property.name: forms
property.documentation: The forms to which input is stored are output here.

property.name: applicationId
property.documentation: The id of the application (this is used as the display name of the application).

property.name: applicationPackage
property.documentation: The id of the application (this is used as the display name of the application).

property.name: angularBase
property.documentation: The location of the angular module.

property.name: angularAppDir
property.documentation: The location of the src/app directory.

property.name: models
property.documentation: The models are generated here.

propertyGroup.name: Configuration
propertyGroup.documentation: The properties that provide configuration of the JSF configuration files.

property.name: facesConfig
property.documentation: The name of the JSF configuration file (this file stores the JSF managed bean form information and navigation rules).

property.name: facesConfigFiles
property.documentation: Comma separated list of URIs of (additional) faces config files. (e.g. /WEB-INF/jsf-config.xml). See JSF 1.0 PRD2, 10.3.2

property.name: formScope
property.documentation: The scope to given the forms. This value can be overriddem by a tagged value.

property.name: controllerScope
property.documentation: The scope to given the controllers.

property.name: navigationBeanScope
property.documentation: The scope to given the navigation items.

property.name: facesServletExtension
property.documentation: The extension used for the application's handling of JSF pages.

property.name: fileUploadMaxMemoryPerRequest
property.documentation: Maximum memory per request (in bytes) for file uploads.

property.name: fileUploadMaxDiskSpacePerRequest
property.documentation: Maximum memory per request (in bytes) for file uploads.

property.name: navigationUsesRedirect
property.documentation: Uses 'redirect' instead of 'forward' to navigate between views.

propertyGroup.name: UI Layout
propertyGroup.documentation: Properties related to the configuration of the user interface layout.

property.name: useAjax
property.documentation: Generate the forms with Ajax support.

property.name: componentSet
property.documentation: The component set to be used. Supported values are primefaces,trinidad.

property.name: maxTableRows
property.documentation: The default value to set for the maximum rows displayed in a table.

property.name: navigationStyle
property.documentation: Controls the way navigation items are displayed

propertyGroup.name: Messages and i18n
propertyGroup.documentation: Properties related to the configuration of messages and internationalization in general.

property.name: applicationName
property.documentation: The name of the application (this is used as the display name of the application).

property.name: normalizeMessages
property.documentation: Denotes the way application resource messages ought to be generated. When messages are normalized it means that elements with the same name will reuse the same label, even if they are located in entirely different use-cases or pages. This results in resource bundles that are not only smaller in size but also more straightforward to translate. The downside is that it will be less evident to customize labels for certain fields (which is rarely the case anyway).

property.name: loginFileName
property.documentation: The path to the file that provides the login page (minus the extension).

property.name: logoutFileName
property.documentation: The path to the file that provides application logout (minus the extension)

property.name: defaultMultiSelectSize
property.documentation: The default size to use for multi select boxes.

property.name: enableFaceletsDevelopmentSupport
property.documentation: Whether or not the Facelet development support should be enabled (in the generated web.xml), this is useful to enable when developing with Facelets, however should be disabled when going to production.

property.name: enableMyFacesDevelopmentSupport
property.documentation: Whether or not the MyFaces development support should be enabled (in the generated web.xml), this is useful to enable when developing with MyFaces, however should be disabled when going to production.

property.name: defaultDateFormat
property.documentation: The default date format to use in case it has not been explicitly specified, for event parameters. Take a look here to see how to properly construct date formats.

property.name: strictDateTimeFormat
property.documentation: Specifies whether or not date and time formats are to be strictly matched. This property takes either true or false as values. If set to true all dates and times entered by the end-user will fail validation if they do not strictly adhere to their given format. Note that this strictness can always be overriden locally using the andromda_struts_view_field_format tagged value.

property.name: defaultTimeFormat
property.documentation: The default time format to use when it has not been explicitly specified for event parameters. Take a look here to see how to properly construct time formats.

property.name: defaultInputColumnCount
property.documentation: If specified denotes the default length of text input fields, the value specifies the size attribute of the corresponding input or textarea element. Not speciying any valid value will make the cartridge ignore it and resort to the default browser value by not rendering any size attribute.

property.name: defaultInputRowCount
property.documentation: If specified denotes the default number of rows of textarea elements. Not speciying any valid value will make the cartridge ignore it and resort to the default browser value by not rendering any size attribute.

property.name: defaultTableExportTypes
property.documentation: The types of files to which a table can be exported.

propertyGroup.name: Validation and Security
propertyGroup.documentation: These properties configure the validation of user input as well as the security.

property.name: securityRealm
property.documentation: The security realm to use when security is enabled. If using the security filter, set it to the Catalina realm that will be adapted to the securityfilter.

property.name: authenticationType
property.documentation: Set the authentication type. Supported values are securityFilter, container.

property.name: loginConfigAuthMethod
property.documentation: The auth-method of the login-config section.

property.name: defaultRole
property.documentation: The default role of all secured elements.

propertyGroup.name: Other
propertyGroup.documentation: Other various properties that couldn't be classified into another category.

property.name: virtualHost
property.documentation: The name to use for the virtual host (if one is required). For example application.myserver.com.

property.name: useCaseForwardsClassName
property.documentation: The name of the class containing all use case forwards.

property.name: sessionTimeout
property.documentation: The number of minutes the session may be idle before timeout occurs.

property.name: distributable
property.documentation: Whether or not the web application should be considered distributable; this means that the session will be persisted and restored.

property.name: ngrx
property.documentation: Whether or not to use NgRX

property.name: useLombok
property.documentation: Whether or not to use Lombok

property.name: stateSavingMethod
property.documentation: The JSF state saving method to use within the application (can be either client or server).

property.name: fileTypeName
property.documentation: The fully qualified type name to use when file types are modeled for parameters (used for for file uploads).

property.name: dummyData
property.documentation: Indicates whether or not dummy data should be rendered (in places like controllers).

property.name: backingListPattern
property.documentation: The pattern used for constructing a parameter's backing list name. A backing list is used when you want to select the value of the parameter from a list (typically used for drop-down select input types).

property.name: backingValuePattern
property.documentation: The pattern used for constructing a parameter's backing value name. A backing value is used with an input table type (when you want to submit values from a table of complex objects).

property.name: labelListPattern
property.documentation: The pattern used for constructing the label list name (stores the list of possible parameter value labels).

property.name: valueListPattern
property.documentation: The pattern used for constructing the values list name (stores the list of possible parameter values when selecting from a list).

property.name: converterPattern
property.documentation: The pattern used for constructing converters (like the enumeration converter), where {0} is the name of the model element.

property.name: managedBeansPackage
property.documentation: Defines the the package in which any extra managed-beans will be generated (such as the layout options class, etc).

property.name: testPackage
property.documentation: Defines the the package in which any extra test classes will be generated.

property.name: xmlEncoding
property.documentation: Encoding for generated XML files.

property.name: formPattern
property.documentation: The pattern to use for constructing the form name, where {0} is the name of the controller operation capitalized.

property.name: formImplementationPattern
property.documentation: The pattern to use for constructing the form implementation name, where {0} is the name of the controller operation capitalized.

property.name: formMessagesProperty
property.documentation: Defines the name of the property on a form that stores messages.

property.name: formBeanPattern
property.documentation: The pattern for constructing the name of the bean under which the form is stored, where {0} is the name of the use case and {1} is the name of the trigger.

property.name: controllerImplementationPattern
property.documentation: The pattern for constructing the name of the controller implementation class name (where {0} represents the modeled name of the controller).

property.name: actionFormKey
property.documentation: The name of the key under which each action for is stored. This form is passed along from action to action in order to transfer all parameters.

property.name: messageResources
property.documentation: The path of the localized message resources (the .properties suffix is appended to this value when creating the actual file.).

property.name: jspIncludes
property.documentation: Defines the name of the default includes file (this contains any message resources as well as tag libs.

property.name: servicePackageNamePattern
property.documentation: The name of the package in which to create the service files, {0} can be used to denote the package in which the service has been modeled.

property.name: serviceAccessorPattern
property.documentation:
The pattern to use when calling the backend code for <<Service>> lookups. For calling services you would use following patterns:
Spring: ${application.package}.ServiceLocator.instance().get{1}()
EJB: ${myPackage}.{1}Util.getHome().create()

property.name: exceptionHandlerPattern
property.documentation: Used to define the pattern used for retrieving message resource keys from exceptions. This is useful when exceptions are thrown from the business tier and you want to map these to messages in your presentation. Normally you won't need to change this pattern, however you may want to if you want to enable it to handle exceptions you may have no control over (i.e. SQLExceptions). Currently the default pattern supports an exception with an embedded {some.resource.key} type key.

property.name: testImplementationOperationNamePrefix
property.documentation: The pattern used to construct the test implementation name, where {0} is the current model element name.

property.name: webserviceStack
property.documentation:
The webservice Stack to use for your webservices, valid values are:
axis
xfire
jaxws
cxf
springws

property.name: wsdlOperationSortMode
property.documentation: Specifies how operations should be sorted within the WSDL. Current options are none and name.

propertyGroup.name: Manageable Entities
propertyGroup.documentation: Properties related to the generation of the web-tier part of the manageable entities (also known as the CRUD feature).

property.name: generateCrudImpls
property.documentation: Generate Impl classes to all manageable entities, despite the andromda_manageable_implementation.

property.name: crudValueObjectSuffix
property.documentation: The suffix to append to the names of generated value objects used in CRUD (manageable entities).

property.name: crudDetailsSuffix
property.documentation: The suffix to append to the names of generated details (in compositions) elements used in CRUD (manageable entities).

property.name: crudConfirmationMessages
property.documentation: Show a confirmation message after each CRUD operation.

property.name: trimInputStrings
property.documentation: Trim form entered strings;
